jQuery 4.0.0 Beta â€” I recently looked at issue #1 of JavaScript Weekly and the top two items were jQuery, so itâ€™s nice to feature it :-) You might not be using jQuery, but it's still everywhere, including WordPress. v4 says goodbye to IE 10 support, removes lots of deprecated APIs, and steps into the modern world just a tad (it even migrated to ESM).

jQuery Foundation

Hunor has recorded a spectacular screencast on reimplementing it in JavaScript, but if you don't like videos, thereâ€™s a detailed written tutorial, too.

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Cytoscape.js: Graph/Network Visualization and Analysis Library â€” Handy if you need to model and/or visualize relational data, like biological data or social networks. There are many demos to enjoy here. GitHub repo.

Max Franz

Announcing TypeScript 5.4 Beta â€” TypeScript gains Object.groupBy and Map.groupBy, a new NoInfer<T> utility type is introduced to stop TypeScript from digging in to match against inner types during inference, and lots of smaller bits and pieces covered in this lengthy post. The final release is expected in March.

Daniel Rosenwasser

FlexGrid by Wijmo: The Industry-Leading JavaScript DataGrid â€” A fast and flexible DataGrid for building modern web apps. Key features and virtualized rendering are included in the grid module. Pick and choose special features to keep your app small. Built for JavaScript, extended to Angular, React, and Vue.

Wijmo from MESCIUS inc sponsor

Deno 1.40: Now with the Temporal API â€” Most releases of the Deno JS runtime seem significant lately, but 1.40â€™s implementation of the Temporal API, decorators, and more WebGPU features ups the ante on the path to v2.

The Deno Team

IN BRIEF:

  • Some Node.js security releases are anticipated next Tuesday (Feb 6.)

  • TIL: The pnpm project maintains a frequently updated benchmark of package managers (well, npm, pnpm and Yarn, anyway.)

  • ğŸ€ Bouncy Ball shows a live comparison of 22 ways to animate a bouncing ball in the browser. Most are JS-based and show the code.

  • Porffor is an experimental, ahead-of-time JS to WASM compiler.

RELEASES:

  • htmx 2.0.0-alpha1 â€“ There's a draft 1.xâ†’2.x migration guide showing what will be affected (not a lot).

  • Puppeteer 21.10.0 â€“ Node.js API for Chrome - now with experimental browser.debugInfo.

  • Neutralinojs 5.0 â€“ Lightweight cross platform desktop app framework.

  • Primate 0.28, Prisma 5.9, Ember 5.6, Pixi.js 7.4

Take a Qwik Break from React with Astro â€” Paul Scanlon compares React to Qwik using several examples and concludes that Qwik is at least worth exploring as a React alternative.

Paul Scanlon

Import Assertions and Import Attributes â€” Shu-yu Guo, of both TC39 and the V8 team at Google, explains how import assertions matured into import attributes and are enabled by default in V8 v12.3.

Shu-yu Guo (V8)

A Next.js App Router Migration: The Good, Bad, and Ugly â€” A team rebuilt their main dashboard from scratch using a modern Next.js approach and hereâ€™s some of what they encountered, good and bad, before concluding that they wish theyâ€™d considered Remix instead.

Brandon Bayer (Flightcontrol)

Improving Enterprise Design Systems â€” Live stream for design system builders and users: How can we make working with design systems more seamless?

StackBlitz sponsor

Squeezing the Last Bit of JS Performance for my Automation Game â€” The author is building CivIdle, a casual â€˜idleâ€™ civilization building game, using Pixi.JS. As an idle game, it needs to simulate time that passed behind the scenes which meant a lot of optimization was in order.

Ruoyu Sun

Starting and Publishing a Library: The Modern Way â€” A walk through the steps involved in creating and packaging a library, publishing a package, adding testing, and automatically publishing it all to the NPM registry.

TamÃ¡s Sallai

How to Test Web Bluetooth with Puppeteer â€” Use Puppeteer to test features that use the Web Bluetooth API in Chrome.

Masso and Beaufort

The Absolute Minimum Every Software Developer Must Know About Unicode â€” A modern extension to a classic 2003 article by Joel Spolsky.
Nikita Prokopov

Tackling Flaky Tests with Cypress and Playwright through Network Synchronization
Shreya Kurian

Why I'm Excited for Biome's Type Inference

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Better JavaScript Shell Scripting with Bun Shell â€” Performance-focused server-side runtime Bun continues its rapid evolution with a side quest into the world of shell scripting by making it easier, cross-platform friendly, and less verbose. zx offers similar (but less integrated and focused) functionality to Node users, if you should prefer.

Jarred Sumner (Bun)

Announcing AdonisJS v6 â€” If you want a backend Web framework with amazing docs and packed with features, Adonis is a good choice. v6 is a big step forward moving to ESM by default, with more type safety overall (including for routes and middleware references), a new validation library, and more.

Harminder Virk

Learn Vite, The Fast Build Tool for Modern Web Projects â€” Join Steve Kinney for this video course tour of Vite's capabilities, including a look at bundling, optimizing static assets, hot module reloading, and its plugin ecosystem. You'll come away proficient at using Vite to build scalable, performant apps.

Frontend Masters sponsor

QuickJS: The Small, Embeddable JavaScript Engine â€” Several years ago, Fabrice Bellard, the genius behind FFMPEG and JSLinux, built a tiny and complete JavaScript engine in C. It now supports ES2023 and its latest release adds top-level await in modules and its REPL, as well as support for some cutting edge JS features (changelog).

Fabrice Bellard

IN BRIEF:

  • @npm_malware on Twitter/X shares malicious packages detected in real time.

  • JetBrains has opened up its Early Access Program for WebStorm 2024.1, its commercial JS/TS IDE.

  • ğŸ“… React Conf 2024 takes place this May 15-16 online and at Lake Las Vegas.

  • Astro 4.2 â€“ The framework that never ceases to amaze.

  • Puppeteer 21.9 â€“ Now using Chromium 121.

  • Next.js 14.1, Qwik 1.4, Expo Router v3, Redux Toolkit 2.1

ğŸ“’ Articles & Tutorials

Web Components in Earnest â€” This is.. epic! If you want to really get a walk through the journey of building an entire app using Web Components and JavaScript, this is it. The app in this case is simple, but complete, and the author shows off the realities of going all in with Web Components here.

David Bryant Copeland

â–¶  An Alpine, HTMX, and Astro-Based Wordle App â€” Popular dev YouTuber Jack demonstrates building a Wordle clone with a modern Alpine, HTMX and Astro-based stack. Or you can go straight to the code, if you prefer.

Jack Herrington

Complete Your AI Coding Experience with Wallaby.js â€” Get instant test feedback and powerful debugging for AI code suggestions.

Wallaby Team sponsor

How to Start a React Project in 2024 â€” Robin explains the pros and cons of a few common approaches, including using Vite, Astro, and Next.js.

Robin Wieruch

Build a Next.js App in Storybook with React Server Components and Mock Service Worker â€” How to develop, document, and test RSC apps in isolation, while using MSW to mock network requests.

Michael Shilman

Reversing and Tooling a Signed Request Hash in Obfuscated JS
Brett Buerhaus

Create a Currency Converter with HTML, CSS, and Vanilla JavaScript
Esther Vaati

ğŸ›  Code & Tools

Jint 3.0: A JavaScript Interpreter for .NET â€” Run JavaScript within a .NET app and expose .NET objects and functions to JavaScript code. v3 arrives after seven years of work and is the most standards-compliant JS engine running entirely within .NET.

SÃ©bastien Ros

Mutative: A Library for Efficient Immutable Updates â€” A library for efficient immutable updates, boasting being 2-6x faster than naive handcrafted reducers, and even more than 10x faster than Immer. GitHub repo.

Michael Lin
